snippet: The deadly fire in an Oakland warehouse has shed light on an illegal housing boom and prompted questions about whether the building should have been shut down....
abstract: Warehouse fire that claimed lives of at least 36 people has raised questions about whether authorities in Oakland, Calif, should have done more to shut down building, which was known by many as illegal home and performance space; Oakland officials say city takes illegal housing seriously, but there are so many informally converted spaces that building inspectors, firefighters and police are overwhelmed by problem.

byline.original: By JULIE TURKEWITZ, THOMAS FULLER, RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA and CONOR DOUGHERTY
byline.contributor: Julie Turkewitz, Thomas Fuller and Conor Dougherty reported from Oakland, and Richard Pérez-Peña from New York. Dai Wakabayashi contributed reporting from Oakland, and Caitlin Dickerson and Niraj Chokshi from New York.

lead_paragraph: The deadly fire in an Oakland warehouse has shed light on an illegal housing boom and prompted questions about whether the building should have been shut down.

headline.main: Oakland’s ‘Ghost Ship,’ Site of Fire, Was a Motley Warehouse With a History
headline.print_headline: Oakland Site Violated Codes but Filled Need
